metadata.title: Large language models for generating disability reports and assigning impairment percentages for health commissions
metadata.description: This study explores the use of artificial intelligence tools to assist health commissions in calculating disability percentages, aiming to alleviate the administrative burden on physicians. The performance of two advanced AI systems, ChatGPT-4 and Data Analyst, was evaluated based on their ability to generate accurate disability reports and percentage calculations for nine realistic patient scenarios. These outputs were assessed using a 5-point Likert scale, focusing on alignment with expert evaluations and established disability guidelines, completeness, and accuracy (absence of false information). The findings underscore the potential of integrating AI tools into health commission workflows to streamline processes and enhance efficiency.

data.title: Large language models for generating disability reports and assigning impairment percentages for health commissions

metadata.title: Qualitative Forschung mit KI: Wie gut können Large Language Models reale Forschungsprozesse abbilden?
metadata.description:
Hintergrund: Der Einsatz von Künstlicher Intelligenz (KI) in der qualitativen Forschung wird derzeit kritisch diskutiert und es gibt erhebliche Bedenken hinsichtlich ihrer Anwendbarkeit für die qualitative Forschung. Es wird argumentiert, dass Large Language Models (LLM) zwar in der Lage seien, Texte zu verarbeiten und Muster zu erkennen, es ihnen aber an interpretativer Tiefe und methodischer Präzision mangele (Mayring, 2025). Bisher fehlen systematische Vergleiche, inwieweit KI-Modelle qualitative Forschungsprozesse unterstützen
können. Insbesondere stellt sich die Frage, ob LLM einen echten Mehrwert für Forschungsteams bieten können, beispielsweise als Forschungspartner in Projekten oder als Werkzeug zur Methodenschulung.

Zielsetzung: Ziel dieser Studie ist es, einzelne Forschungsergebnisse unterschiedlicher LLMs mit realen, manuell durchgeführten qualitativen Forschungsergebnissen zu vergleichen.

Methode: Diese Studie führte einen systematischen Praxistest durch und simulierte einen vollständigen qualitativen Forschungsprozess mit verschiedenen KI-Modellen. Anhand eines realen Forschungsprozesses wurde jeder Schritt einzeln simuliert – von der Entwicklung der Interviewfragen über die strukturierte qualitative Inhaltsanalyse bis hin zur Ableitung von Handlungsempfehlungen. Die simulierten Daten der KI-Modelle GPT-4o, Llama 3.3 70b und Mistral 8x7B wurden anschließend mit den Ergebnissen des realen Projektes verglichen. Dabei wurden Übereinstimmungen zwischen den KI-Tools und den realen Daten in den
einzelnen Forschungsschritten systematisch bewertet.

Ergebnisse: Die KI-Modelle lieferten in vielen Bereichen vergleichbare Ergebnisse mit realen Forschenden. Jedoch zeigten sich Schwächen bei der Erfassung feiner semantischer Nuancen sowie bei der tiefgehenden Interpretation von Texten. Problematisch waren falsche Ausgaben, die durch ein Anpassen des Prompts oder eine erweiterte Anfrage an das System allerdings richtiggestellt werden konnten. Die Handlungsempfehlungen der KI waren oft plausibel, blieben jedoch an der Oberfläche. Insgesamt zeigt sich, dass LLM nicht als Ersatz
für qualitativ Forschende fungieren, aber eine wertvolle Ergänzung darstellen können – sei es zur Simulation von Forschungsprozessen vor der Datenerhebung, zur Schulung qualitativer Forschungsmethoden in der Lehre oder als Forschungspartner in Forschungsprojekten.

Implikation für Forschung und (Versorgungs-)Praxis: Die Ergebnisse verdeutlichen, dass eine LLM als Forschungspartner in der qualitativen Forschung Potenzial hat, insbesondere zur Entlastung bei standardisierten Analyseaufgaben und zur Simulation von Forschungsprozessen für die Lehre oder als Plattform für einen Pretest. Zukünftige Forschung sollte sich darauf konzentrieren, spezifische Optimierungsstrategien für den KIEinsatz in qualitativen Forschungsprojekten zu entwickeln.

Literatur:

Mayring, P. (2025). Qualitative Content Analysis With ChatGPT: Pitfalls, Rough
Approximations and Gross Errors. A Field Report. Forum Qualitative Sozialforschung Forum:
Qualitative Social Research, 26(1). https://doi.org/10.17169/fqs-26.1.4252

data.title: Qualitative Forschung mit KI: Wie gut können Large Language Models reale Forschungsprozesse abbilden?

metadata.title: Investigating Gender Bias in Large Language Models Through Text Generation
metadata.description: Large Language Models (LLMs) have swiftly become essential tools across diverse applications such as automated content creation, personal writing aids, language translation, and academic writing. However LLMs also raise significant ethical and societal concerns, particularly regarding potential gender biases in the text they produce. This study investigates the presence of gender bias in four Large Language Models (LLMs): ChatGPT 3.5, ChatGPT 4, Llama 2 7B, and Llama 2 13B. By generating a gendered language dataset using these LLMs, focusing on sentences about men and women that include gender-coded words from gender lexicon, we analyze the extent of gender bias in the outputs of these LLMs. Our evaluation is two-fold: we use the generated dataset to train a gender stereotype detection task and measure gender bias in the classifier, and we perform a comprehensive analysis of the LLM generated text at both the sentence and word levels. Gender bias evaluations in classification tasks and lexical content reveal that all the LLMs demonstrate significant gender bias. ChatGPT 4 and Llama 2 13B exhibit the least gender bias, with weak associations between gendered adjectives used and the gender of the person described in the sentence. In contrast, ChatGPT 3.5 and Llama 2 7B exhibit the most gender bias, showing strong associations between the gendered adjectives used and the gender of the person described in the sentence. This study underscores the need for continuous efforts to mitigate gender bias in LLMs to prevent the perpetuation of harmful stereotypes in LLM-generated texts. It also highlights the importance of cautious scrutiny when utilizing LLM-generated text in contexts sensitive to gender issues.

meeting.title: Investigating Gender Bias in Large Language Models Through Text Generation

data.title: Investigating Gender Bias in Large Language Models Through Text Generation

metadata.title: 3D OBJ models of cores from the Middle Stone Ages sites of Ha Makotoko, Lesotho, and Rose Cottage Cave, South Africa

Siemssen, T, Arthur, C, Dewar, G, Lombard, M, and Mitchell, PJ. 2025. Multi-scalar analysis of a southern African assemblage: The Middle Stone Age at Ha Makotoko, Lesotho. Journal of Paleolithic Archaeology, in review.

metadata.title: The intersection of business and artificial intelligence in healthcare: Opportunities and ethical challenges
metadata.description: This dissertation seeks to examine the connection between business and artificial intelligence (AI) in the health sector, major possibilities, and the current ethical issues. It is evident that adoption of AI has revolutionized healthcare by improving clients’ satisfaction, productivity and cost by using technological tools such as analytical tools, tele surgery, and disease diagnosis. This is important because the global AI healthcare market has been estimated to grow to $45.2 Billion by 2026. The study of two different countries – the United States and the United Kingdom – offers an understanding of AI implementation, legislation, and ethical standards as the result of different health systems and legislation. This work reveal potential benefits are enhanced diagnostic accuracy, cost savings whereas the potential harms include violations of patient privacy, bias in algorithms, and accountable issues. The target field adopts theoretical concepts such as The Technology Acceptance Model and The Diffusion of Innovation Theory to review factors affecting AI uptake. This also looks into ethical considerations as a way of making sure that properly applied. The implications of the chosen regulatory frameworks as tools for the analysis of business and patient care strategies are demonstrated in the studied examples of GDPR and HIPAA. The studies provide practical recommendations for both healthcare organizations and policy-makers as well as companies that are importing AI into their services. In conclusion, this research provides to the improvement of healthcare while exploring the signals for confronting the moral issues of AI application on global healthcare settings

creators.name: Hwang, Jin young
creators.affiliation: University of Edinburgh MA Social Policy and Economics, United Kingdom.

data.title: The intersection of business and artificial intelligence in healthcare: Opportunities and ethical challenges

metadata.title: Workflow Database Analysis
metadata.description:
Workflows: Database Analysis

This dataset contains all workflows and scripts to identify structure-property linkages in Kadi4Mat.
The workflows are implemented in the freely available workflow software KadiStudio.

These are the uploaded workflows:

Database Preparation Workflow

(see DatabasePreparation.png)

DatabasePreparation.flow:

  • A workflow to extract data from Kadi4Mat and transform them into tfrecords

The workflow uses the scripts:

DataAcquisition.py:

  • Downloads and processes all metadata in a given collection

DataConversion.py:

  • Converts the extracted metadata into tfrecords
  • Input and output features can be selected. 

Database Training Workflow

(see DatabaseTrainingWorkflow.png)

Datenbase_Training.flow:

  • A workflow to train a neural network on the data extracted from Kadi4Mat

The workflow uses the script:

Datenbase_Training.py:

  • Implements the training of a fully connected neural network
  • Hyperparameters are passed to the script by the workflow

Database Material Map Workflow

(see Create_Materialmap.png)

Create_Materialmap.flow:

  • A workflow to create a material map from the network trained in Database_Training.flow

The workflow uses the script contained in this folder:

Create_Materialmap.py:

  • Systematically iterates over the input properties of the neural network
  • Visualises the predictions in a material map

metadata.title: RSFC: Research Software Fairness Checks
metadata.description:
• More tests added
  • Better code structure and data management
  • New table console output
metadata.notes: If you use this software, please cite it using the metadata from this file.

metadata.title: Workflow Simulation
metadata.description:
Workflows: Simulation

This dataset contains all workflows and scripts to simulate the mechanical properties of foam structures. 
The workflows are implemented in the freely available workflow software KadiStudio. The simulation is performed using PACE3D.

These are the uploaded workflows: 

Simulation Workflow

(see SimulationWorkflow.png)

Simulation.flow:

  • A workflow to simulate the mechanical properties of binary foam structures
  • Downloads the foam structures from a given Collection on Kadi4Mat
  • Requires the simulation framework [PACE3D](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jocs.2018.02.011)

The workflow uses the scripts contained in this folder:

foam_mechanical_load_plastic.infile:

  • Configuration file used to parameterise PACE3D

Evaluate_Simulation.m:

  • Extracts the effective mechanical properties from the simulation results
  • Outputs compressive modulus and yield strength

metadata.title: ML-based Generation of digital twins
metadata.description:
Workflows: Generation

This dataset contains all workflows and scripts to train a DD-GAN for generating microstructures and to generate new structures using the DD-GAN. 
The workflows are implemented in the freely available workflow software KadiStudio.

These are the uploaded workflows: 

Train DD-GAN Workflow

(see Training_DD-GAN.png)

DD-GAN_Training_Kadi.flow:

  • workflow to train a DD-GAN for generating three dimensional structures
  • Requires a binary image stack of the structure to mimic
  • Generation can be tuned to be conditioned by properties or images

The workflow uses the scripts:

warmup.py:

  • Creates a file that contains the information about all used subvolumes
  • Requires binary images that are used for training

Train_DD-GAN_props.py:

  • Trains a DD-GAN conditioned on structural properties
  • Outputs a structure generator 
  • Requires binary images of the structure to mimic and the info file generated by warmup.py.

Train_DD-GAN_images.py:

  • Trains a DD-GAN conditioned on images   
  • Outputs a structure generator
  • Requires binary images of the structure to mimic and the info file generated by warmup.py

Generation DD-GAN Workflow

(see Generation_DD-GAN.png)

DD-GAN_Generierung_Kadi.flow:

  • A workflow to generate three-dimensional structures using a DD-GAN
  • Requires a trained model
  • Generation can be tuned to be conditioned by properties or images
  • The workflow implements random and targeted generation

The workflow uses the python scripts contained in this folder:

warmup.py:

  • Creaes a file that contains the information about all used subvolumes
  • This file is required for the random generation

Generate_DD-GAN_props.py:

  • Generates structures conditioned on properties
  • Outputs image stacks of the generated microstructure
  • Requires binary images of the structure used for training and the info file generated by warmup.py.

Train_DD-GAN_images.py:

  • Generates structures conditioned on images   
  • Outputs image stacks of the generated microstructure
  • Requires only the trained model
